awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a High-Performance Computing Cluster for Research and Teaching at UC Irvine
awd_abstract_narration:
This acquisition provides a modern, energy-efficient, campus-wide, High-Performance Computing Community Cluster (HPC3) enabling research and research training in areas ranging from elementary particle physics and quantum chemistry through earth-system modeling and engineering to social ecology. HPC3 is expected to deliver a combination of high flexibility and user friendliness with high efficiency for both massively parallel and shared memory applications that is not always achievable by centralized supercomputing or cloud computing facilities.

The acquisition is a mixed CPU/GPU cluster that provides substantial computing power to a diverse, high-performance computing (HPC) community of 13 major user research groups as well as other researchers and students at the institution and three local partnering campuses of California State University. The acquisition will also be used by researchers across the Nation by virtue of HPC3's integration with the Open Science Grid (OSG) and eXtreme Science and Engineering Discovery Environment (XSEDE).  Examples of research projects that will use HPC3 include: new elementary particle discovery, first-principles simulations of high-temperature superconductors and quantum spin liquids, simulations of warm dense matter, electronic structure of small-gap compounds, nonadiabatic molecular dynamics simulations of photocatalysts and light-driven materials, Monte Carlo
simulations of crowded protein solutions, thermodynamic properties of pharmaceuticals, RNA sequencing, alignment of biological networks, ice-sheet modeling, global climate modeling including cloud effects, geophysical climate data analysis, multiscale materials modeling, and simulations of turbulent flow.   

All partnering universities are Hispanic-serving institutions, and minorities underrepresented in the Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) fields will be actively recruited through mentoring and outreach on campus and to local high schools in underserved areas. HPC3 will also support the development of highly optimized HPC software used by scientists worldwide for simulations in condensed matter physics, quantum chemistry, computational fluid dynamics, and earth system science.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The funding for this project was used for the acquisition of a high-performance heterogeneous CPU-GPU cluster named HPC3 that supports a diverse community of researchers and students at the University of California Irvine, and local partnering California State University campuses. The HPC3 cluster became operational in June 2020 and general production started in September 2020. The HPC3 cluster supported 891 users and handled 7.6M jobs successfully in one year from 2020-21 supporting a variety of applications sizes from single for 1K+ cores. 


The equipment has been successfully used for various research projects including optimizing snow/ice melt retrievals from high-resolution Antarctic ice sheet simulations, simulating particle collisions at the Large Hadron Collider, evaluating environmental justice and infrastructure permitting processes in California, generating quantum chemical data for molecular mechanics, molecular dynamics simulations, Monte Carlo simulations, and ab initio quantum chemical simulations to name a few. The above research has resulted in several publications, senior undergraduate and graduate theses.


In addition to advancing several research disciplines, HPC3 also supported several educational activities, including 12 undergraduate and graduate courses, high-school outreach programs, and hackathons. California State Summer School for Mathematics and Science (COSMOS), an intensive four-week summer residential program at UCI, used the HPC3 cluster in 2021. This opportunity enabled talented students completing grades 8-12 hands-on experience on a state-of-the-art computing facility which is far beyond the courses usually offered in California high schools. The UCI machine learning hackathon ran on HPC3 in Spring 2020. Over the 7 days of the hackathon, teams developed machine learning approaches for the challenge datasets contributed by the UCI research community from different domains such as environmental, ethical, health, etc.


UCI is a leading university serving a diverse population of students and has been once again ranked the number one university for economically diverse students. UCI was named a Minority-Serving Institution (MSI) and Hispanic-Serving Institution (HSI) by the US Department of Education since one-quarter of our undergraduates identify as Latino and half of all students receive financial aid. UCI was also recognized as an Asian American and Native American Pacific Islander-Serving Institution (AANAPISI) in 2017. The computing resources provided by HPC3 are now indispensable for preparing the next generation of diverse interdisciplinary computational scientists and engineers. The Research Cyberinfrastructure Center at UCI ensures that working structures for community-centric decision making and oversight, administrative and technical support, collaboration, shared training and teaching, data management, and long-term maintenance are in place. The HPC3 cluster will continue to support the UCI campus community and partnering California State University campuses for several years to come.
